questions.question: What is the closest planet to the Sun?
questions.explanation: Mercury is the smallest planet and closest to the Sun, with temperatures reaching 800¬∞F (427¬∞C)!

questions.question: How many moons does Earth have?
questions.explanation: Earth has one natural satellite - our Moon! It's about 1/4 the size of Earth.

questions.question: What is the largest planet in our solar system?
questions.explanation: Jupiter is massive! It's so big that all other planets could fit inside it.

questions.question: What causes meteor showers?
questions.explanation: When Earth passes through a comet's debris trail, we see meteors burning up in our atmosphere!

questions.question: How long does it take for light from the Sun to reach Earth?
questions.explanation: Sunlight travels 93 million miles (150 million km) to reach us in about 8 minutes and 20 seconds!

questions.question: Which planet is known as the 'Red Planet'?
questions.explanation: Mars appears red because its surface contains iron oxide (rust)!

questions.question: What is a light-year?
answers: A year with lots of light
Distance light travels in one year
Time for Earth to orbit Sun
questions.explanation: A light-year is about 6 trillion miles - the distance light travels in one year!

questions.question: If an asteroid travels 25,000 km/h, how far does it travel in 2 hours?
questions.explanation: Distance = Speed √ó Time. 25,000 √ó 2 = 50,000 km!

questions.question: Earth is about 150 million km from the Sun. What's this in scientific notation?
questions.explanation: 150 million = 150,000,000 = 1.5 √ó 10‚Å∏ km. This distance is called 1 Astronomical Unit!

questions.question: If Earth's diameter is 12,800 km, what's its radius?
questions.explanation: Radius = Diameter √∑ 2. So 12,800 √∑ 2 = 6,400 km!

questions.question: The Moon is about 384,000 km from Earth. How many Earth diameters is this?
questions.explanation: 384,000 √∑ 12,800 = 30. The Moon is about 30 Earth-widths away!

questions.question: If you weigh 60 kg on Earth, you'd weigh about 10 kg on the Moon. What's the ratio?
questions.explanation: Moon's gravity is 1/6 of Earth's, so you weigh 6 times less there!

questions.question: What protects Earth from most asteroids and meteors?
questions.explanation: Our thick atmosphere burns up most small space rocks before they reach the ground!

questions.question: What are asteroids mostly made of?
questions.explanation: Asteroids are leftover rocky and metallic material from when our solar system formed!

questions.question: Why do we see meteor streaks in the sky?
questions.explanation: High-speed friction with air molecules heats meteors until they glow!

questions.question: What's the difference between a meteor and a meteorite?
answers: One hits ground, one burns up
questions.explanation: Meteors burn up in the atmosphere. If pieces survive and hit the ground, they're meteorites!

questions.question: What force keeps planets orbiting the Sun?
questions.explanation: Gravity! The Sun's massive gravitational pull keeps all planets in orbit.

questions.question: If asteroids A, B, and C are approaching Earth, and A is fastest, C is slowest, what order will they arrive?
questions.explanation: Fastest arrives first! Order: A (fastest), B (medium), C (slowest).

streakBonusQuestions.explanation: Sir Isaac Newton! His law of universal gravitation explains how gravity works throughout the universe.

streakBonusQuestions.question: üî• STREAK BONUS: How many astronauts have walked on the Moon?
streakBonusQuestions.explanation: 12 astronauts walked on the Moon during 6 Apollo missions between 1969 and 1972!

funFacts: The asteroid belt contains millions of asteroids, but they're so spread out that spacecraft can easily fly through!
Some asteroids are actually 'rubble piles' - loose collections of rocks held together by gravity.
The metal in a single small asteroid could be worth billions of dollars on Earth!
Asteroid Vesta is so bright you can sometimes see it with the naked eye from Earth.
Some asteroids have been found to contain water ice - important for future space exploration!
The largest asteroid, Ceres, has its own atmosphere and may have an underground ocean.
Asteroids come in different types: rocky (S-type), metallic (M-type), and carbon-rich (C-type).
NASA's DART mission successfully changed an asteroid's orbit in 2022 - planetary defense in action!
